snippet: Jabbar Collins, who is suing the city after 16 years in prison for a murder he says he did not commit, claims falsely notarized warrants were used to coerce testimony.
abstract: Jabbar Collins, who is suing New York City after 16 years in prison for a murder he says he did not commit, claims falsely notarized warrants were used to coerce testimony; Michael F Vecchione, assistant prosecutor in office of Brooklyn District Atty Charles J Hynes, testifies that several affidavits sworn and notarized in his name in 1995 had actually been signed by others.
lead_paragraph: Jabbar Collins, who is suing the city after 16 years in prison for a murder he says he did not commit, claims falsely notarized warrants were used to coerce testimony.

headline.main: Notarized Signatures Weren’t His, a Brooklyn Prosecutor Testifies
headline.print_headline: Notarized Signatures Weren’t His, a Brooklyn Prosecutor Testifies
